comment: Because it's no longer about sustaining a company with healthy, long-term growth
It's about generating as much money as possible for all time
In gaming cos it was the originality
Big BLOCKBUSTER titles ALL THE TIME
I'm gonna love watching the investors and shareholders cry when loot boxes are banned globally
loot boxes have generated insane amounts of profit for gaming companies
But they are literal gambling and exposed to kids, so what else would happen?
That’s mostly what they want, kids get mommies and daddies credit cards and spenf frivioulusly
Europe is going to do it first
Several nations have already banned loot boxes in games, and more are on the verge of doing so
Yeah, they are pretty common senseical
What would make me extra happy is if global governments took these companies to court
Fined them tens to hundreds of millions in damages for their unethical behavior
Yeah, but no money in THAAAAT
The industry is defending loot boxes tooth and nail
It's pretty clear they know that they're in the wrong on everything, but the cash flow is too damn good
So they'd rather fight for that small chance that they can keep these things legal, rather than roll over and admit fault
Yeah, won’t change if the measure of success if money
It’s funny when you take the product out of the picture and you realize an economy is just a bunch of people tricking each other into giving eachother money for shiny, sparkly things.
:ctwokinds-zenshocked: “omg, my brain likes this... how much?”
But as for owning "fancy things".  I like what I like.
No joke, super / hypercars are neat and all
But I *really* like the body of 1970's mustangs and such
In one of the Forza games I own, my primary car is a Shelby Cobra
Literally just dump all my cash into upgrading that thing
The new ones are kinda goofy
I liked the mid 2010 ones though too
If it looks good an functions well, I don't need some money dump
Oh yeah find the best compromise of good stuff to money ratio
I don't play the lottery anymore, but if I did, I would maybe have some of the after-tax money as spending money
But invest the rest and live off the passive income
And if that proves to be too much, start donating
Maybe start shifting investments to promising up and coming companies
Don't need a yacht, I don't really care for / want to be on boats
Don't need a private jet.  Giant waste of space / emissions nightmare
Would rather play games / make stuff, lol
Hell, there's an idea... art college
A good one that doesn't run students $160,000 - $240,000 over 4 years

The thing that still bothers me is that, while providing rigor to refine yourself, take tom for example, college itself isn’t going to gurantee you develop a style or anything you’re not already capable of.
Oof... apparently building a college can be upwards of $2,000,000,000
Some people do thrive in the school environment.
But that all depends on size / scope

School is a good way to find some people who might know what they’re talking about to get you a credential into corporate america, but make sure you bring a passion... or at least hope you bring one that is compatible with what the market is looking for.
I would argue that an art school is an effective way to get you to try out many things, and find what you like and what you are good at
And then get you to focus on that and improve your skill in a timely fashion
A primary example of this is 3d animation
Most art colleges will tech you everything.  Modelling, rigging, animation, lighting & effects
Yeah, certain higher order things it’s tough to get exposed to
But you need to specialize to get a career.  Although there are paths where you can make it as a generalist
That's why there are services such as animation mentor / iAnimate / bloop, that specialize in character animation
That’s why access and net neutrality are important, WHY is it that there is a $XX,000 gate on learning skills YOU NEED to compete and participate in society?
It’s like a purposeful limit to maintain classism
Also, uni's get you access to industry software included in the tuition :P
So not only do you learn things in a focused manner, you get access to the relevant tools
It’s like “YOU paid the troll toll, now you have the privilege of TRYING to make something out of yourself”
Like really, it’s all just bluster and misdirect for money being incorrectly allocated at the top.
“You peasants can squabble, while we induldge~”
But yeah it costs to establish and run a college, what should happen eventually though is they become so commonplace as highschools or something
Then thats when SUPERcollege becomes a thing
I think the prestige they have is no longer deserved, at least not in exchange for higher cost.
Arguably, at some point college will become the new high school
In the past, school in general was something for the upper class
But it was decided that a K-12 education was something that everyone deserved
Given the increasing necessity of degrees to get a "living wage", at some point we can no longer justify the absurd increases in costs
Tbh, I really don’t see how colleges are treated as ‘prestegios’ and ‘sophisticated’ when EVERYONE knows what college life is actually like.
I honestly never thought I'd join the $15 crowd, but I'm joining that crowd

Well now I'm in a bad mood...
This is the video that just set me off: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UCWoTtF8LAo
"Blizzard Employees Are Protesting With Spreadsheet Compiling Awful Salaries & Wage Disparity"
It's like damn Dave Chappelle mayne, guy split from the whole program and lived in South Africa for like 15 years when he realized how stilted the whole mess is.
He really just wanted equal profit sharing and appropriate creative control.
Execs had other ideas, he split.
Just gotta stop appeasing those in power
What's really sad is that nothing is likely to change unless the entire economy implodes...
they just find the next stiff to do their bidding
The people at the top with the endless cash flow will keep lobbying / "bribing" politicians for policies that favor their interests
It's like a thrill for them, to buy people
And unless people at all levels stand up to this unethical greed, it's only going to get worse...
What's super sad is that there's an easy way to fix this whole problem
Apparently there's a group out there that already has a suggestion
Worker co-ops are becoming a bigger trend
CEO can only earn 100x as much as the lowest paid employee.
So if bobby kotick wants to keep making 40,000,000+ in compensation, his "cheapest" employee better be making 400k a year
I'm sure the buorgosiese are going "Oh, how cute"
But... what if Adira is technically rich?
if you think Adira has got anything on, say, Trace
Anyways, I'm slowly getting on board with this idea...
Her actual money may be short. but her heart is TALL
That you need to cap how much a CEO or anyone else can make in compensation relative to the lowest paid employees
Because in activision Blizzard's case... they will pay you as little as possible so they can funnel all the extra money into the pockets at the top
check out how german corporations work - the board has membership representing the employees
We need to get laws changed for that to work
As it stands, the courts have determined that the company exists onlyt o make money for the investors / shareholders
So that precedent needs to be overturned right effing now
It's impossible to build a publicly traded company on the idea of health, sustained, long-term growth
The greedy pigs will just sue to remove you, and will keep doing so until they get someone who will play ball
Cuz American high-skilled labor has absolutely zero unions
Remove that precedent, then they can't remove you just because theyd on't like how you're running the company
That opens the door for CEO's who want the company to grow in a healthy way
Like what college educated person thought that was a good idea?
yeah professional unions are very rare
I've only been half joking for years of unionizing the engineers at my company
Like the fact that highly skilled people accept they don't have strength in numbers is crazy
I understnsd the idea of individual bargaining and whatever
mostly it's the lack of support and that I'm lazy
After we can open the door for CEO's who think long term, we can start working on flushing the boards of greedy individuals who support the status quo
but it's like they gave up the ability to fight as a whole in exchange for selling their soul
We can open the way for getting employee approved board members

it's on its way to the core
